Subject: Prison Ship Repairs
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=197581214; y=Vtf7rZIZJcpBWut2yAUOplIzLFg_aOvpKDAVUR7ACI9Uchw

A few weeks had passed.  The upper hull had been completely repaired
and mo=
st of the controls in the cockpit had been returned to working
order.  The =
ship's computer was non-existent however.  In the fighting
that had occurre=
d when Celeron had broken in, and when one of the
prisoners had decided to =
go on a murderous rampage, the computer had
been summarily reduced to a pil=
e of silicon and wires.  Although
Celeron had attempted to reconstruct it, =
the project had never been
finished, and now no one aboard the ship had any=
 idea how to fix it.

Most of the outer hatches and doors had been replaced=
 using the scrap
metal from one of the cargo holds and the prison block had=
 been
reinforced to prevent another escape.  The remaining crew now returne=
d
to the cargo bay for another strategy meeting and a review of the work
th=
at had been completed.

At the table sat Farelwave (the captain), Tigon (th=
e warden of the
prison block), Betaspiel (a pilot turned repairman), and a =
couple new
faces Rector and Cyphia (both released from stasis only a few da=
ys
prior).  Rector had been the 2nd in command of the security forces
when =
the ship had been operational, but now he wasn't certain what his
role woul=
d be.  Cyphia was a communications technician, not only did
she know how to=
 maintain, repair, and build communication equipment,
but she also knew how=
 to decode encrypted frequencies.  However due to
the circumstances, none o=
f the crew were really performing their
original duties.

"I would like to =
welcome you back to our crew.  I will begin this
meeting by giving a brief =
on our standing as far as repairs and
location of missing crewmen.

First o=
f all, aside from bringing you two out of stasis, we had not
located any mi=
ssing crewmen, we will likely be bringing the other
three out of stasis whe=
n we are absolutely certain that they were not
put into stasis because of l=
ife-threatening complications, and since
none of us are doctors, that could=
 take some time."

There was a brief pause, the captain smiled and Rector a=
nd Cyphia
smiled back nervously.

"As far as the repairs go, the cockpit is=
 completely repaired, minus a
few key components: the navigation computer, =
the communications panel,
and the ship's computer.  The prisoner that has b=
een repairing the
cockpit circuitry has been able to repair many of the con=
nections in
the security system, and its computer appears to be undamaged, =
however
we do not have the reactor up in running, and so we cannot power up=

the systems to do a diagnostic.

The hull has been repaired on about 90% o=
f the surface of the ship
that is visible now, I estimate that the buried p=
ortion of the ship
constitutes another 40% of the total surface area, meani=
ng we're a
little over half-way done with basic external repairs.

The task=
 now, is to go down into the sections of the ship that contain
the reactor =
and engines.  That area of the ship was sealed off when we
crashed, and sin=
ce we no longer have the ship's computer, I cannot
determine what happened =
down there.  There are three hazards that
could be present down there: 1. R=
adiation, 2. Escaped Prisoners, 3.
Our Fellow Crewmen mistaking us for pris=
oners/enemies/intruders and
shooting us on sight."

Tigon then turned to th=
e captain, "I only have 5 prisoners that are
unaccounted for. According to =
my records though two of them are highly
dangerous and natural-born leaders=
, so all of the missing prisoners
are still alive and they are down there, =
then we might have to
postpone going in there until we have the other three=
 out of stasis. 
5 on 5 odds are not good."

The captain responded "I agree=
, the other two problems are also good
reason why we must take some time to=
 prepare.  We are all trained to
fight, but I know that these prisoners wer=
e incarcerated for a reason,
and judging by the two of these we had to figh=
t, I'm certain that we
will have great difficulty defeating them if they ha=
ve organized.

Finally, I think it would be wise to attempt to clear out a =
room and
convert it into a vault or armory that we could use as shelter in =
an
emergency and also store our valuables in case we need to leave for
any =
reason.  If anyone would like to volunteer for this project please
say so n=
ow, otherwise I will see to it myself.  Now I will open this
meeting up to =
anyone who would like to speak.

Betaspiel raised his hand.  "I would like =
to help you in that project
sir.  I would also like to see if we can repair=
 one of the backup
power systems and get power to the cockpit and the light=
s in the areas
that we are currently using."

"Good idea, we can give that =
task to our inmate, just get me a plan on
paper so I can make sure he has a=
 good idea of what we expect from
him.  Cyphia, what were you planning to d=
o."

"Well... I was planning to take a look at all the systems in the
cockp=
it, I hope that we can get some power running to it soon.  I can
assist in =
the external repairs until we have power there.  I haven't
had the chance t=
o go outside yet."

"Good, and Rector?"

"It doesn't appear like anybody ha=
s gone into the other rooms the the
lower deck that we do have access to.  =
I would like to take a look
around and then I can bring any weapons to the =
vault when it is
ready."

"Ok.  And Tigon, I assume you will be leading the=
 work on the
exterior, correct?"

Tigon nodded.

"Ok, then I will now go to=
 attend the next stasis chamber.  You are
all dismissed"

Everyone split up=
, left the cargo bay, and began their work.

OOC: I haven't posted on this =
thread since March.  I figured it would
be a shame to let it go. I'll try t=
o post more on it, let my know if
you like it or not.  Or if you have any s=
uggestions.  Yahoo IM:
titobeau  ^_^  Adios
